newsitem.title: FRANCE: FOCUS-BAe bids for US fighter at Paris show.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-BAe bids for US fighter at Paris show.

text.p: An announcement by British Aerospace Plc (BAe) to team up with giant Lockheed Martin to bid for a next-generation U.S. fighter sent an adrenaline shot on Wednesday through the Paris air show.

The Joint Strike Fighter is the Pentagon's attempt to squeeze maximum value out of a shrinking budget by buying a common airframe for the U.S. Air Force, Navy and Marine Corps, which all currently fly different aircraft. The British navy is also buying the futuristic fighter.

"With a requirement for over 3,000 aircraft, JSF is the most significant transatlantic military programme of the 21st century" BAe chief executive Richard Evans said in a statement released at the air show.
BAe's decision ends intense speculation over whether it would join Lockheed or rival bidder Boeing Co in developing two prototypes apiece by 2001, with a planned entry into service in 2008.

The JSF is expected to generate at least $100 billion in revenues for the winner over the life of the programme, with one senior U.S. aerospace executive estimating the price tag at $35-40 million price per plane, depending on the version.

While fighter jets scream overhead and lightweight planes dance to the Blue Danube played over loudspeakers in the flying demonstration, down below, executives huddle to cut corporate deals and horse-trade over orders, which are the lifeblood of this intensely competitive business.

In Europe, eyes are rivetted on Lagardere group and telecommunications giant Alcatel Alsthom, the rival bidders in the privatisation of French defence electronics firm Thomson-CSF, launched by the previous conservative government.
The state sell-off is widely seen as key move in a consolidation of French and European defence capacity, needed to confront U.S. competition from the likes of Lockheed Martin.
Lagardere said it was ready to adapt to the new setting since the election of a Socialist-led French government and would continue to pursue a linkup with Thomson-CSF.
"We think the Thomson-Matra merger remains the only answer to the dynamism of the Americans," Matra High Technology chairman Noel Forgeard told reporters.
"Will the merger between Thomson-CSF and Matra be done on the same terms? I cannot say. The rules will be set, we will adapt to them," he said.
Matra, which is a Lagardere subsidiary, has allied itself with Daimler-Benz Aerospace AG (Dasa) of Germany and British Aerospace Plc in its bid.
But Alcatel chairman Serge Tchuruk told reporters his company's bid was still valid. "Our plan has not lost any of its industrial qualities. There is no reason for it to lose them."
Alcatel joined with privately-owned Dassault Industries for its bid and has assigned a large role for joint ventures with state-owned Aerospatiale in its business plan for Thomson-CSF.

Orders announced on Wednesday included Brazilian airline TAM's purchase of up to 10 of European aircraft consortium Airbus Industrie's A330-200 widebody twin-engined jets in a deal valued at around $1 billion.
U.S. airline Continental Express also ordered 25 EMB-145 regional jets, worth around $350 million, from Brazilian aircraft maker Embraer.
